docs.lead_paragraph: Now is the time to prepare for the next epidemic, before it is upon us.
docs.snippet: Now is the time to prepare for the next epidemic, before it is upon us.

docs.lead_paragraph: If resistance to the drug, artemisinin, were to spread, it could hamper treatment of a disease that kills hundreds of thousands a year, mostly in Africa.

headline.main: Malaria in Widening Area Resists Drug, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Malaria in Widening Area Resists Drug, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study published in journal The Lancet Infectious Diseases finds that drug artemisinin, world's most effective treatment for malaria, is losing its efficacy in much larger swath of territory than was previously believed; area where deadliest form of disease is increasingly resistant to drug includes part of Cambodia, Myanmar and India.
docs.snippet: If resistance to the drug, artemisinin, were to spread, it could hamper treatment of a disease that kills hundreds of thousands a year, mostly in Africa.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a little known disease but it could make medical history if scientists' predictions are correct: yaws could completely disappear by 2020, given the right resources.

headline.main: Diseases Affecting the Poorest Can Be Eliminated, Scientists Say
headline.print_headline: Diseases Affecting the Poorest Can Be Eliminated, Scientists Say

docs.snippet: It is a little known disease but it could make medical history if scientists' predictions are correct: yaws could completely disappear by 2020, given the right resources.

headline.main: Genes Tell Only Part of the Story
headline.print_headline: Genes Tell Only Part of Story

docs.abstract: The lives of patients are far more complex, and messier, than science can explain.
docs.snippet: The lives of patients are far more complex, and messier, than science can explain.

docs.lead_paragraph: While Beijing’s air quality has generated more headlines worldwide, scientists say New Delhi’s air is often significantly worse, but only now are residents turning to surgical masks and air purifiers.

headline.main: Delhi Wakes Up to an Air Pollution Problem It Cannot Ignore
headline.print_headline: Delhi Wakes Up to Problem It Cannot Ignore

docs.abstract: New Delhi residents, in major attitude shift, are beginning to react to city's air pollution, which is considered most toxic in the world; many say that while major policy change by India's government is unlikely, growing recognition is first step to addressing problem.
docs.snippet: While Beijing’s air quality has generated more headlines worldwide, scientists say New Delhi’s air is often significantly worse, but only now are residents turning to surgical masks and air purifiers.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study provides stark evidence that the need to help people quit is more important than ever.

headline.main: The Smoking Toll Gets Much Worse
headline.print_headline: The Smoking Toll Gets Much Worse

docs.abstract: Editorial highlights study published in New England Journal of Medicine finding that smoking is even more harmful to health than previously thought; calls on government to expand efforts to help smokers quit, particularly state governments in the United States through programs like Medicaid.
docs.snippet: A new study provides stark evidence that the need to help people quit is more important than ever.

docs.lead_paragraph: Smartphones will empower patients to take charge of their health care, a cardiologist argues.

headline.main: ‘The Patient Will See You Now,’ by Eric Topol

docs.abstract: Sandeep Jauhar reviews book The Patient Will See You Now: The Future of Medicine Is in Your Hands by Eric Topol.
docs.snippet: Smartphones will empower patients to take charge of their health care, a cardiologist argues.
